div1.p: Peabody discusses the Camp Lazear memorial project. He wishes to know if Hench has been contacted by Wood.

div1.head: Letter from James E. Peabody to Philip Showalter Hench, February 8, 1942
div1.p:
Your letter of Jan. 28th. is full of
good news. I am so glad to learn
of the interest of the Cuban Govern-
ment in the Yellow Fever Memorial,
of your visit with Mrs. Walter Reed,
and of your good fortune in getting
the material from the Dr. Lazear
home.

You have never told me how you
first became interested in this epic
story. If I had only known that
all this research was to be carried on
after the Bill was passed by Congress.
You may be sure I would have been
only too glad to turn over to you all
that material I destroyed when I gave
up my research room at the Harvard
Laboratories.

I wonder if you have received any
communication from a Laura Wood.
Dr. Flexner suggested she send on to
me certain questions relating to Major
Reed. It seems she is writing a book
about him for young people. Isn't
it odd that there is so much interest
in this Yellow Fever story, after all that
25 years of neglect?

I shall hope to hear more good
news from you one of these days.
